docs.abstract: LEAD: The United States agreed today to send $1.5 million worth of wheat seed to Bangladesh to replace seed washed away by recent flooding. The United States has also given a $25,000 emergency grant and has donated $15 million worth of rice, the Agency for International Development announced. Floods in Bangladesh in July and August killed 700 people, created hardship for 23 million others, polluted water supplies, and destroyed more than two million acres of farm land, the agency said.
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States agreed today to send $1.5 million worth of wheat seed to Bangladesh to replace seed washed away by recent flooding. The United States has also given a $25,000 emergency grant and has donated $15 million worth of rice, the Agency for International Development announced. Floods in Bangladesh in July and August killed 700 people, created hardship for 23 million others, polluted water supplies, and destroyed more than two million acres of farm land, the agency said.

docs.abstract: LEAD: Bangladesh is seeking emergency international aid for the victims of floods that have afflicted one-sixth of its 105 million people, Government officials said today.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bangladesh is seeking emergency international aid for the victims of floods that have afflicted one-sixth of its 105 million people, Government officials said today.

docs.abstract: LEAD: AFTER the police fired on anti-Government protesters here last week, the leading opposition party in Bangladesh scheduled a prayer service for three slain partisans. But its leader was unable to attend. Sheik Hasina Wajed, the Awami League's head, is a woman, and Moslem tradition dictates that women be barred from ceremonies for the dead.
docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER the police fired on anti-Government protesters here last week, the leading opposition party in Bangladesh scheduled a prayer service for three slain partisans. But its leader was unable to attend. Sheik Hasina Wajed, the Awami League's head, is a woman, and Moslem tradition dictates that women be barred from ceremonies for the dead.

docs.abstract: LEAD: President H. M. Ershad ordered a fresh crackdown on his opponents today as their national strike against his Government continued to cripple the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: President H. M. Ershad ordered a fresh crackdown on his opponents today as their national strike against his Government continued to cripple the country.

headline.main: Crackdown Is Ordered In Bangladesh Strikes
headline.print_headline: Crackdown Is Ordered In Bangladesh Strikes

docs.abstract: LEAD: Six weeks after the political opposition opened a campaign of protests to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad, there is no sign that the Government and its opposition will come to a settlement soon.
docs.lead_paragraph: Six weeks after the political opposition opened a campaign of protests to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad, there is no sign that the Government and its opposition will come to a settlement soon.

headline.main: Stalemate in Bangladesh Drains the Economy
headline.print_headline: Stalemate in Bangladesh Drains the Economy

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.abstract: LEAD: The Government dissolved Parliament today, almost a month after the opposition began a campaign of strikes and demonstrations to topple President H. M. Ershad.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Government dissolved Parliament today, almost a month after the opposition began a campaign of strikes and demonstrations to topple President H. M. Ershad.

docs.abstract: LEAD: Bangladesh's two main opposition leaders were freed from house arrest today and said they would not negotiate with the Government of President H. M. Ershad.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bangladesh's two main opposition leaders were freed from house arrest today and said they would not negotiate with the Government of President H. M. Ershad.

docs.abstract: LEAD: President H. M. Ershad said today that new parliamentary elections would be held within three months.
docs.lead_paragraph: President H. M. Ershad said today that new parliamentary elections would be held within three months.

docs.abstract: LEAD: The monsoon rains are at their most pitiless now in Bangladesh, a country regularly victimized by wind and water.
docs.lead_paragraph: The monsoon rains are at their most pitiless now in Bangladesh, a country regularly victimized by wind and water.

headline.main: FOR BANGLADESHI OPPOSITION, A CRICIAL PERIOD
headline.print_headline: FOR BANGLADESHI OPPOSITION, A CRICIAL PERIOD

byline.original: By Barbara Crossette, Special To the New York Times

docs.abstract: LEAD: Jainab Begum, who says her age is about 30, marched through the streets of Dhaka the other day along with 300 other flood victims demanding food and work.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jainab Begum, who says her age is about 30, marched through the streets of Dhaka the other day along with 300 other flood victims demanding food and work.

headline.main: Misery Rising In the Floods In Bangladesh
